author: Michael Gadd for MailOnline
title: Police investigating man who 'started two fires' on Monarch Airlines plane
text:
76 shares 2
View
comments
West Midlands police have launched an investigation into a passenger who allegedly started two fires deliberately during a packed Monarch Airlines flight from Birmingham to Sharm El Sheikh.
A passenger on board said the man lit small blazes in the plane's toilet cubicle 'while also smoking and abusing the cabin crew, terrifying crew and passengers'.
The fire was extinguished by cabin crew and police in Egypt were waiting for the A321 aircraft with 201 passengers when it landed in the Egyptian resort on August 27.
A passenger allegedly lit two fires on a Monarch Airlines flight from Birmingham to Egypt's Sharm El Sheikh
With the plane unable to fly following the incident, tourists due to fly back to England on the same day were left stranded for almost 24 hours.
The Airport Policing Unit is now looking further into the incident, and although no arrests have been made fellow travellers believe the suspect was questioned by authorities in Egypt.
Those stuck in Sharm El Sheikh were put up in a hotel by the airline.

'Hearty cheers, finest libations and sundowners': The... 76 shares Passenger Tarek Mohammed previously told the Birmingham Mail after the incident: 'We were not told our flight was cancelled until 20 minutes after take-off time. There were no official representatives from Monarch.
'Passengers were given each others' personal information and were asked to sort out the chaos.
'There are 200 disappointed Monarch passengers.'
The incident on board a Monarch A321 aircraft is being investigated further by West Midlands police
A female passenger, who wasn't named, told the paper: 'The plane was unserviceable because a man set fire to onboard toilets deliberately while also smoking and abusing the cabin crew, terrifying crew and passengers.'
She praised the Monarch crew for the way they dealt mid-flight with the 'idiot', who while being escorted from the plane 'showed no remorse and verbally abused the passengers whose flight was cancelled'.
The passenger said the delayed travellers were put up in a 'lush luxury hotel' and it 'wasn't entirely Monarch's fault'.
A West Midlands Police spokeswoman said: 'We have launched an investigation after two small fires are believed to have been deliberately started on a Birmingham flight bound for Egypt.
The flight landed safely with the suspect escorted away by Egyptian authorities, but those due to return to England on the same flight were left stranded for 24 hours
'The fires were contained and extinguished by staff aboard the Monarch flight from Birmingham to Sharm El Sheikh and no-one was injured.
'Officers from the Airport Policing Unit continue to investigate the circumstances around the incidents.'
A Monarch Airlines spokeswoman added: 'The A321 aircraft, which was carrying 201 passengers and seven crew, landed safely in Sharm El Sheikh where local police were in attendance. UK authorities have been notified and are dealing with the matter.
'As the alleged incident is the subject of a police investigation, we are not in a position to comment further.'
